history.content:
I have to agree that attending live lecture is much better, because you have a chance to ask the professor to clarify some points right away, then you can spend more time in office hours doing homework instead of trying to understand the lecture material. If you absolutely can't make the lecture, course Piazza is a good place to ask questions as well.

Note: This semester (Fall 2017) CS 61C does not require iClicker.

I have to agree that attending live lecture is much better, because you have a chance to ask the professor to clarify some points right away, then you can spend more time in office hours doing homework instead of trying to understand the lecture material. If you absolutely can't make the lecture, course Piazza is a good place to ask questions as well.

children.subject:
I actually think webcasts are almost always better in helping me absorb the material for the simple reason that you can go at your own pace. 2x speed through the easy to comprehend parts, slow down/pause to really think through the hard parts and to take good notes. It should average out to around the same amount of time as actually going to lecture in my experience.

The only thing is that it's easier to fall behind if you keep pushing off the watching lectures. Stay on top of it. I'm currently enrolled in 170 and got well over 1 SD on midterm 1. I've only attended the first lecture, and usually lightly skim the textbook, but I watch every webcast and go to discussion section and work through homework problems as much by myself as I can. This has been a successful way for me, and you should do whatever you think will make you successful.

history.content: Is it better to attend lecture? I plan to take 61C and 170 next semester, which have conflicting lecture time, and 61C requires iClicker attendance. Some friends told me that 170 is not good to watch webcast without attending lecture, can someone please share opinion on this?
history.subject: Is watching webcast of 170 good?
